2022.expert_review:
Competes with: Ford Mustang Mach-E, Hyundai Ioniq 5, Kia KV6, Tesla Model Y, Volkswagen ID.4

Looks like: A sleeker Audi Q5

Drivetrains: 201 horsepower (estimate) with single motor or 295 hp (estimate) with dual electric motors; 82-kilowatt-hour lithium-ion battery; rear- or all-wheel drive

Hits dealerships: Late 2021

The list of electric vehicles available from major automakers planning to challenge the dominance of Tesla is about to grow by two models, as Audi has taken the wraps off its 2022 Q4 E-Tron and Q4 E-Tron Sportback models. They mark the lowest-price, entry-level, electric-vehicle crossovers from the German luxury brand, riding on a dedicated EV platform and offering an estimated maximum of 250 miles of range, according to the manufacturer. 

Related: 2022 Audi E-Tron GT: Premium Efficiency

Exterior

Size-wise, the new Q4 E-Tron and Q4 E-Tron Sportback are dimensionally similar to Audi’s compact Q5 crossover, so smaller than Audi’s other EV SUV, the original E-Tron. The company says that the footprint is the same as the Q5, but that the Q4 E-Tron brings the next generation of EV styling to the Audi lineup, albeit in the smallest entry-level model available for sale. The standard Q4 E-Tron will be an SUV, while the Sportback model gets the “crossover coupe” treatment with a lower, racier roofline and truncated cargo area that ends in a two-part window and deep, integrated spoiler. Both models put a special emphasis on aerodynamics, with the Q4 E-Tron achieving a 0.28 coefficient of drag, while the Sportback manages an even better 0.26. Both models will be offered with all of Audi’s signature styling elements, like the S Line and Black Optic exterior styling options and the animated coming-home and leaving-home dancing head- and taillight patterns. New to the system: The driver can choose between four different running-light signatures via the onboard multimedia system.

Interior

On the inside, it’s an expected move to a “glass cockpit” for the Q4 models, including an optional flat top-and-bottom steering wheel with touch-sensitive controls and capacitive hands-on detection for semi-autonomous driving aids. Audi claims that the interior is roughly the same size as the Q5, but the Q4 E-Tron features better passenger space due to the elimination of the transmission tunnel and improved legroom thanks to a flat cabin floor. The center 10.1-inch multimedia interface (Audi MMI) display is angled toward the driver and features a floating panel below it that houses the electronic shifter above an additional storage cubby. The gauge cluster is a standard 10.25-inch digital affair; it can be upgraded to Audi’s signature Virtual Cockpit look for additional functionality, such as full-screen navigation. An optional augmented reality head-up display is available, superimposing information like driver assistance features, speed and navigation aids onto the windshield but appearing to be projected roughly 30 feet in front of the driver and interacting with outside elements like lane lines and other vehicles. A new Sonos premium audio system will be available, marking that brand’s debut with the German automaker.

2022 Audi Q4 E-Tron | Manufacturer image
Under the Hood

The new Q4 E-Tron and Q4 E-Tron Sportback are powered by a common battery system, an 82-kilowatt-hour gross rating, meaning the full size of the battery and 77-kwh net, which is the usable portion of the battery for driving the car. It’s a liquid-cooled lithium-ion pack that sits in the floor between the axles to lower the vehicle’s center of gravity. The crossover can be had in one of two configurations: The Q4 40 E-Tron is a single-motor, rear-wheel-drive model that makes an estimated 201 hp, while the Q4 50 E-Tron quattro and Q4 50 Sportback E-Tron quattro are dual-motor all-wheel-drive models, adding a motor to the front axle and bumping output to an estimated 295 hp. Recharging can be done via an up to 11-kilowatt AC circuit or up to 125 kilowatts on a DC fast charger. 

Handling and driving performance are managed by the McPherson front axle and five-link rear suspension setups, as well as the Audi drive mode selection system that allows varying driving profiles like Efficiency, Comfort, Dynamic and customizable Individual. The range champ will be the Q4 40, which Audi estimates will achieve roughly 250 miles in the U.S. EPA cycle; range estimates or recharging times for the rest of the lineup are not yet available. 

A full complement of driver assist and semi-autonomous driving aids will also be available, including Audi Pre-sense, side and lane assist, and high-beam headlight assist. Adaptive cruise control will be offered with lane keeping and Traffic Jam Assist.

Pricing and Availability

The ’22 Audi Q4 E-Tron and Q4 Sportback E-Tron will arrive in U.S. dealerships toward the end of 2021, according to the company, with the least expensive model expected to start under $45,000 (not including destination fee or any available tax credits or rebates) for a Q4 40 E-Tron. The company hopes it will also qualify for a $7,500 federal tax credit as well as other local incentives depending on geographic region. Other pricing and additional specs will be made available closer to the vehicle’s on-sale date.

2023.expert_review:
The verdict: Carrying the cachet that comes with an Audi badge, the Q4 e-Tron family of electric SUVs do very little poorly or foolishly and are a “normal” option for shoppers who aren’t as daring as some EV early adopters.

Versus the competition: While not as sporty or powerful as similarly sized or priced premium electric SUVs, the Q4 e-Tron and Q4 Sportback e-Tron are accessible and intuitive models that make a strong case for themselves as SUVs that just happen to be EVs.

Audi is expanding its electric vehicle portfolio and adding a smaller, more affordable model in the Q4 e-Tron, which is available in a traditional SUV body style and coupelike version named the Q4 Sportback e-Tron. I traveled to Oceanside, Calif., (per Cars.com’s ethics policy, we pay for our flights and lodging when attending such manufacturer-sponsored events) to spend a brief time behind the wheel and poking around the two versions to see where they stand in the constantly growing electric SUV field.

Related: 2022 Audi E-Tron S and E-Tron S Sportback: More Money, More Power, Less Range

The Q4 e-Tron is available in single-motor rear-wheel-drive form or with dual motors and all-wheel drive, but the Q4 Sportback e-Tron is AWD-only. The battery pack is an 82-kilowatt-hour unit no matter which version you get. If those basic facts sound familiar, that’s because the Q4 e-Tron shares much of its underlying architecture with the Volkswagen ID.4 SUV.

I drove 2022 versions of the Q4 at the drive event, but this model year is sold out and changes for 2023 are minimal; for 2023, there’s a larger touchscreen (using the same software), the S Line appearance package is now standard on AWD models and wheel choices are slightly different.

Driving the Q4 e-Tron

Having already driven the VW ID.4, the Q4 e-Tron felt familiar — and not in a bad way. Power is relatively modest for an EV, with single-motor RWD versions rated at 201 horsepower and dual-motor AWD models making a healthier 295 hp. With an Audi-estimated 0-60 mph time of 5.8 seconds, the dual-motor version is no slouch, but most of its quickness is felt from stoplight to stoplight, where the electric motors’ instant torque gets to play. There’s still some power in reserve for highway passing and merging, but at higher speeds, the Q4 e-Tron has less oomph. Changing drive modes does little to change the character of the car; throttle response doesn’t feel different, and the steering gets slightly heavier. Personally, I preferred the weightier steering feel of the Q4 e-Tron’s Dynamic mode.

Braking with the brake pedal and not the regenerative system feels linear and easy, like a decent set of brakes in a gas-powered car. That’s still a relatively uncommon trait in EVs, which often have brakes that feel mushy or lack feedback, but this sort of traditional feel makes the Q4 e-Tron more accessible to drivers who are new to EVs.

A curious omission is the lack of true one-pedal driving. The Q4 E-Tron offers three levels of regenerative braking, with the most powerful nearly bringing the car to a complete stop before a final press of the brake pedal is needed. Regeneration strength can be adjusted via paddles on the steering wheel, or you can simply select the strongest setting by selecting the “B” driving mode via the gear selector. I preferred the highest-strength setting while driving around town and for managing speed when descending larger hills; it saved me when passing a motorcycle cop posted at the bottom of a hill, where coasting would’ve had me exceeding the speed limit significantly. On twistier roads, however, the drag from the regeneration system was noticeable and unsettling, and I preferred to forgo it.

The Q4 e-Tron’s steering is nicely weighted and communicative, and is tuned for everyday driving. The SUV’s 33.5-foot turning circle (37.7 feet with AWD) makes it feel maneuverable and nimble in low-speed parking and parking-adjacent situations.

Ride quality feels slightly firmer than the ID.4 and roughly on par with the Volvo XC40 and C40 Recharges, Genesis GV60 and Tesla Model Y. You’ll feel bumps, potholes, expansion joints and other road imperfections in the cabin, but they aren’t unsettling. Having a chance to drive all of these vehicles back-to-back on the same roads would provide a more definitive ranking, of course, but know that the Q4 e-Tron’s ride is comfortable and unlikely to upset you or your passengers.

Road, tire and wind noise seem more present than in a gas-powered SUV, but that’s to be expected when there isn’t an internal-combustion engine to drown out much of those sounds. I did notice some extra wind noise at higher speeds, however.

Forward visibility, despite the forward position of the A-pillars, was decent from my seating position. Rear visibility is lacking, however, particularly in the Sportback; the rear head restraints obstruct the view behind, and the Sportback has a rear spoiler that splits the rear windscreen and blocks your view.

Interior

On one hand, the Q4 e-Tron’s interior impresses with its traditional layout that is unlikely to scare away shoppers. The control layout is straightforward, with physical climate and audio controls and, blessedly, four window switches on the driver’s side (the ID.4, for whatever reason, has two switches and an additional toggle to control the front or rear windows). Also impressive is its infotainment system, which is the traditional Audi MMI system we’ve seen throughout the brand’s lineup. Unlike the ID.4’s occasionally confusing system, MMI works easily and intuitively.

On the other hand, the controls on the steering wheel are touch-sensitive, something both we at Cars.com and consumers in general don’t enjoy. To Audi’s credit, the controls do provide haptic feedback and aren’t as fraught as the ones used by Mercedes-Benz. Audi’s controls require actual intentional presses, whereas turning the steering wheel in a Benz might lead to multiple unintentional inputs. Still, the Audi’s steering wheel controls are sometimes hard to see in direct sunlight, and I’ll always prefer real buttons to facsimiles.

Interior materials quality is adequate. There are a lot of hard plastic surfaces, especially below the beltline, and some buyers might find that disappointing in a vehicle that can cost more than $60,000. The plastic in particular stands out with lighter-colored upholstery; the all-black interior looks the nicest.

Interior room is impressive both front and rear. Up front, the low, nontraditional gear selector adds to the feeling of roominess. The center console, however, has minimal storage space that’s difficult to reach. The backseat feels like you’re sitting in a class-larger vehicle, though rear headroom in the Sportback is an issue for taller passengers. I’m 6-foot-1 and my head was firmly planted in the Sportback’s roof despite cutouts in the headliner to increase headroom. If you’re constantly hauling taller passengers, the regular Q4 e-Tron is a better bet than the Sportback.

Interestingly, the opposite is true when it comes to cargo — at least according to Audi’s measurements. Audi says the Q4 e-Tron has 24.8 cubic feet of cargo space with the backseat upright and 53.1 cubic feet with the backseat folded; the Q4 Sportback e-Tron, with its coupelike roofline and all, measures at 26.1 and 54.4 cubic feet, respectively. Those aren’t massive differences, but they are surprising. Obviously, taller cargo is more easily stored in the Q4 e-Tron, but we’ll have to wait until we can conduct our own cargo measurements to see how the two compare.

Regardless of body style, the Q4’s cargo area has useful configurability. A cargo floor panel can move to change the load floor height or create a divider to prevent cargo from shifting, and in its regular position, it covers an underfloor storage area where things like the standard mobile charger can be stored.

More From Cars.com:

What to Know Before Purchasing an Electric Vehicle: A Buying Guide
What It Cost to Outfit 6 Homes With EV Chargers
Research Electric Vehicles
Shop for an EV
Range and Charging

Range is an area where the Q4 e-Tron and Q4 Sportback e-Tron won’t wow shoppers, maxing out at an estimated 265 miles for the RWD Q4 e-Tron and 236 miles for the AWD model (the Q4 Sportback e-Tron has an Audi-estimated 242 miles of range). Those range estimates are roughly competitive with Volvo’s compact electric SUVs and the Genesis GV60, but they trail the Model Y and certain versions of the Hyundai Ioniq 5 and Kia EV6. During my drive on a mix of roads at varying speeds, I observed consumption of around 3 miles per kilowatt-hour, which is in line with the vehicle’s efficiency estimates.

Does the Q4 e-Tron’s lower range estimates matter? Possibly, if you’re set on using it for road trips; according to Audi, it can DC fast-charge at up to 150 kilowatts, which can charge the battery from 5% to 80% in as little as 36 minutes. That’s not nearly as impressive as the fast-charging capabilities of the EV6, Ioniq 5 and GV60, and suggests the Q4 e-Tron’s primary mission is as a second or commuter vehicle.

Audi Q4 e-Tron Sportback | Cars.com photo by Brian Normile

All Q4 e-Trons include a 40-amp Level 2 mobile charger that enables the vehicle to charge at up to 9.6 kW from a 240-volt outlet, reaching a full charge in an Audi-estimated nine hours. With 48-amp Level 2 charging, the rate increases up to 11.5 kW and charging time decreases to 7.5 hours. For the latter, buyers will need a hardwired charger, and Audi is partnering with Electrify America and Qmerit for charger sourcing and installation for buyers who want help with a home-charging setup.

Where Does the Q4 e-Tron Fit?

The Q4 e-Tron is, visually and functionally, an exceedingly “normal” SUV that feels like a regular SUV that happens to be electric. With Tesla attracting a particular kind of bleeding-edge consumer and many manufacturers taking a more futuristic approach when it comes to styling, the Q4 e-Tron just wants to be an SUV for luxury-minded buyers.

With the single-motor RWD model starting at just under $50,000 and prices for the AWD model rising to well over $60,000 with options, the Q4 e-Tron occupies a very premium, near-luxury space in the class. But for that money, buyers get a competent EV that drives well and has an intuitive interior — and for those who care, it has that luxury-brand badge.

2025.expert_review:
What Is the 2025 Audi Q4 e-Tron?

The Audi Q4 e-Tron is an electric compact SUV that seats five and offers a choice of a traditional upright-roofline version or a more rakish, fastback-roof variant called the Q4 e-Tron Sportback. The single-motor, rear-wheel-drive 45 powertrain makes 282 horsepower and comes only in the regular Q4. The dual-motor, all-wheel-drive 55 powertrain makes 335 hp; it’s optional in the regular Q4 and standard in the Sportback. The 45 and 55 are available in Premium and Premium Plus trim levels, while the line-topping Prestige trim is restricted to the 55. The Q4 e-Tron shares its basic platform with the Volkswagen ID.4, and its competitors include the Cadillac Optiq, Genesis GV60 and Electrified GV70, Mercedes-EQ EQB and Volvo EX40.

What’s New on the 2025 Q4 e-Tron?

The Q4 e-Tron’s entry-level powertrain is renamed 45 (it was previously called 40); it gains 81 hp and sees a 23-mile increase in driving range, to 288 miles total. The previously optional Technology Package is now standard across the board; it includes navigation, connected services, road-sign recognition and a digital instrument panel. A new Cold Weather Package is available for the 55 and includes a heat pump, which regulates cabin temperature more efficiently than a traditional climate-control system, along with a heated windshield.

How Much Range Does the 2025 Audi Q4 e-Tron Have?

The Q4 e-Tron’s EPA-estimated driving range is 288 miles for the RWD 45 powertrain and 258 miles for the AWD 55 powertrain (for both regular and Sportback versions). 

How Long Does It Take to Charge the 2025 Audi Q4 e-Tron?

When using a 240-volt Level 2 charger, the Q4 e-Tron fully recharges in about 12 hours. When using a DC fast charger, the Q4 e-Tron goes from 10% to 80% charge in about 30 minutes.

What Features in the 2025 Audi Q4 e-Tron Are Most Important?

Standard features include:

Leather upholstery
Power-adjustable driver’s seat
Heated front seats
Tri-zone climate control
Panoramic sunroof
Power liftgate
11.6-inch infotainment touchscreen
10.25-inch digital instrument cluster
Wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto
Blind spot warning
Rear cross-traffic alert
Traffic-sign recognition
Rain-sensing wipers
Front and rear parking sensors

Available features include:

Hands-free power liftgate
Memory settings for the driver’s seat
Power-adjustable passenger seat
Auto-dimming rearview mirror
Wireless device charging
Heated steering wheel
Heated windshield
Heat pump
Lane departure steering assist
Park assist
Sonos surround-sound stereo
Headlight washers
Head-up instrument display
Sport-tuned suspension
Should I Buy the 2025 Audi Q4 e-Tron?

The Q4 e-Tron inherits many of the virtues of the VW ID.4 with which it shares a platform, and it adds enough upscale trim and features to make its higher price palatable. The model lineup offers decent variety, but note that choosing the pricier, racier-looking Sportback version brings compromises in cargo versatility and rear visibility. In any of its forms, the Q4 e-Tron’s driving range and charging speed trail those of class leaders.

Notable features: Sportback SUV coupe body style available
335 hp and 0-60 mph in five seconds (55 trim)
Up to 288 miles of EPA-rated range (45 trim)

2024.expert_review:
The verdict: Familiar battery and motor upgrades along with suspension tweaks bring the top-trim 2024 Audi Q4 e-Tron electric SUV neatly in line with the brand’s image and character, even if it’s far from perfect.

Versus the competition: The dual-motor Q4 e-Tron 55 is (significantly) up on price and down on range when compared to the ultra-popular Tesla Model Y, but customers wishing to avoid the Tesla ecosystem will struggle to find a better choice than the Q4 from established luxury brands.

Well, that was quick. Just a few months after a weeklong sesh in the updated 2024 Volkswagen ID.4, a 2024 Audi Q4 e-Tron hummed up to my front curb with patch notes suspiciously similar to the refreshed V-Dub. Just like its refurbished cousin, the fresh-squeezed Q4 gets a raft of tasty powertrain changes aimed at boosting the big three: power, range and charging speed.

Related: 2024 Audi Q4 55 e-Tron Replaces Q4 50, Gets More Power and Greater Range

2024 Audi Q4 e-Tron | Cars.com photo by Conner Golden
Can I See Your ID(4)?

It’s hard not to draw comparisons here. Both the ID.4 and Q4 e-Tron utilize the same iteration of the Volkswagen Group’s MEB platform and share the same electric motors and batteries, with differences primarily in interior materials, dynamics and styling. New cell chemistry for the standard 82-kilowatt-hour battery pack (77 kWh usable) and a revised rear motor in all-wheel-drive models are the central updates, boosting max range in the dual-motor 55 (previously 50) trim level by 22 miles to an EPA-rated 258 miles. These battery updates also significantly improve the Q4’s maximum charging rate, which is now 175 kilowatts on a DC fast charger instead of 150 kW. (It still charges at up to 11.5 kW on a Level 2 charger.)

Audi also futzed with the Q4’s suspension and steering, now retuned to bring it more in line with the brand’s balanced, sporting character. A higher-performance SQ4 e-Tron remains hypothetical, but the 335-horsepower Q4 e-Tron 55 is poky enough that any dynamic improvement is welcome.

This is the first time I’d driven a Q4 of any type, so while I can’t speak to differences in how the new 55 and now-discontinued 50 trims drive, I can speak to how the Audi operates as a pricier alternative to the ID.4 and how it fares in the greater electric SUV ecosystem.

2024 Audi Q4 e-Tron | Cars.com photo by Conner Golden
EV Road Trip? Think Ahead

Other than standard use as an errand runabout in suburban Los Angeles, I enlisted the Q4 for a mini road trip down to a media program in Encinitas, Calif., a highway cruise that usually would cover 95 mostly flat miles door to door. However, a catastrophic wreck closed all lanes right at a critical junction in the drive, forcing a 50-mile detour through mountain passes that threatened — at least on paper — to drain the brimmed 258-mile range to near-zero by the time I could roll into the valet lot. 

Conscientious driving allowed me to skip a planned mid-route charge stop (not that I really had a choice). Another non-Tesla electric vehicle, another frustrating public-charging experience; the sole Electrify America station on the detour route was queued six cars deep, with only three of the six chargers functioning. This is to say nothing of the two separate EA charging misadventures in my neighborhood that had me waiting around 45 minutes for a single 150-kW DC fast charger. This is nothing against the Q4, but it reaffirms our recommendation that you should have a Level 2 home charger as part of owning an EV. 

2024 Audi Q4 e-Tron | Cars.com photo by Conner Golden
How Does It Drive?

I digress. The Q4 made it to my overnight with roughly 80 miles of range to spare after the mountainous road-trip adventure, and it was expectedly efficient returning to L.A. over open, flat highway the next morning. Though slowed by detour traffic, the Q4 55 proved fun to drive on squiggly canyon roads thanks to its low center of gravity and instant torque that’s enough for an Audi-estimated 5-second 0-60 mph scoot — a 0.8-second improvement over the 50 trim. It has enough pull to gap hot hatches on an entrance ramp, but enthusiasts might want to wait for that hypothetical SQ4. 

Like the VW (as well as the mass majority of modern EVs), driving the Q4 e-Tron is a wholly artificial experience, with very little steering feel and braking granularity — and considering the target audience, that’s just fine. The suspension and steering tuning was sporting enough to match the character and capability of the brand’s Q5 or Q7 SUVs, and the Q4’s ride quality is nice. 

Brake blend — that is, the balance between pure regenerative braking and the engagement of the physical brakes — is well done, with the brake pedal mostly easy to modulate. I’m still not a fan of the Germans’ continued opposition to full one-pedal driving, and both the VW and the Audi are frustrating in this regard. Like the ID.4, the Q4’s braking drive-selection mode increases off-accelerator resistance a fair amount, but not nearly enough for one-pedal driving and will not allow for a full stop. A pair of paddles mounted to the steering wheel control three levels of regen aggression, but make sure you toggle them to Manual mode in the vehicle settings, as pressing the accelerator in Auto will obnoxiously cut resistance back to zero.

2024 Audi Q4 e-Tron | Cars.com photo by Conner Golden
Kit and Kaboodle 

Inside is where the Audi gathers distance on its VW source material. In my loaded example, leather and wood veneer trim and (mostly) soft-touch surfaces are expected affairs for the brand, as is Audi’s excellent MMI digital architecture backing the configurable 10.25-inch digital driver display and 11.6-inch center infotainment touchscreen. We’ve spent too many words previously decrying VW’s use of touch-sensitive controls in the ID.4 and other models, but I found the Q4’s textured, frosted plastic capacitive controls more usable and reactive than VW’s glossy touch surfaces. Plus, redundant hard-button controls for climate functions is a tremendous improvement over VW’s frustrating capacitive slider setup. 

With an extensive feature set including a premium Sonos sound system, heated front seats, a heated steering wheel and a head-up display, it’s silly to consider the top-shelf Q4 “sparse,” but the digitization of most functions renders the cockpit a smidge visually austere and empty. This, when combined with stiff leather and extensive plastic trim, makes the cabin feel about as luxurious as a top-spec A3 or Q3 — not necessarily a bad thing or a deal breaker, but a top Q4 e-Tron is considerably more expensive than those two models.

After a week and a short road trip in each, I believe a top-spec $66,940 Q4 e-Tron makes more sense than a $55,000 VW ID.4, but it’s not that simple; the Tennessee-built ID.4 qualifies for a $7,500 federal tax credit, while the German-built Audi does not. But, from a pure touchy-feely perspective, the updates elevate the 2024 Audi Q4 e-Tron into exactly the electric compact luxury SUV the gradually maturing EV market needs.
